body:
Fantastic, thanks a lot! :-)
io.zipkin it is!
@adriancole sounds good to me, can you get twitter to just point zipkin.io at GitHub's nameservers for CNAME purposes?

@rtyler I just added you to have manage products ability on godaddy, so
lemme know if that didn't work.

Look like keeping this independent on the Scala traits question was a bit optimistic! My view on that is that it is insufficient and doesn't address what this issue is for.

As @jpinner just described, there is a lot of value in a Java backend, as well. I think if we were to prioritize, elimination of client side Scala needs to come first. I don't think that is sufficient, however. The process of producing Java backend components will be helpful in componentizing things such that the ecosystem can support both Java and Scala backends without making it mutually exclusive.

I'm happy to see effort here! Thanks so much for helping. I don't know what
is idiomatic is SBT, but clarifying and deduping sounds like a step
forward. I will test this against my WIP code for Kafka tomorrow AM Pacific
time.
cc @rtyler @abesto
ps JDK 8 happened to be in the same commit, but I've no strong feelings about that.

Multi-module sbt projects often have monolith build definitions inside project/, I think one of the reasons is that it's easier to share common configuration between modules (versions of Scala, Finagle, for example)
I'm not sure if that's possible to do in any other way. I've had some multi-module projects with separate .sbt files in every module, which I eventually refactored to have everything in the same build file.
Oh, looks like you made it work! Disregard my comment ;-)

Disregarded :)

On a more serious note: I have very limited actual experience with the long-term maintenance of multi-project builds. Do you foresee more problems with the many-`build.sbt`s approach, or is it just that it's extra effort to initially get it to work?
mostly about the effort ;-)
Looks very good! +1 But maybe squash them into 1 commit?
Thanks! How about having these three commits?
That looks good to me! :-) +1 for merge, let's just wait for another reviewer then
:shipit: (also prefer less commits, ideally 1)
is this obviated by #478
@adriancole nope, #478 continues the work in this, but does very different things and has very different scope, so I thought a separate PR was in order.
:shipit: as currently everything is hosed and this makes things better.
rebased over latest decoupled build
@jamescway PTAL

https://issues.sonatype.org/browse/OSSRH-16669

I'd like a backup.. @eirslett @michaelsembwever @abesto @kristofa @aasta .. can one or more of you register on https://issues.sonatype.org and add a comment ^^ with your username?

One thing that separates Zipkin from in-house applications is the need to replace backend technologies like Cassandra/MySQL/HBase. So simple flags might not be enough - e.g. MySQL may have other configuration options than Redis. In that regard, configuration as code is actually quite nice...

The way we configure Zipkin today (with Scala files and eval) is actually quite close to Spring XML configuration, except it's Scala, so we actually ship the Scala compiler with the Zipkin distribution (which of course increases artifact size and dependency tree quite a bit). I think we even load the Scala compiler in-memory as part of Zipkin, but I'm not quite sure how the eval module is written.

You can use `@Rule` in Scala if you use JUnitSuite:
http://doc.scalatest.org/1.7/org/scalatest/junit/JUnitSuite.html

Then you won't need the painful `$.MODULE$` stuff that comes from bad Java-Scala-interop... (I'm working on making Span more Java-friendly!)
Thx will change it!
![bummer man](http://memecrunch.com/meme/3GJIW/bummer-man/image.png)
@eirslett Travis is running the build on a Linux box, is that not good enough? :)
I'm going to merge this now, looks like it didn't break anything - but it definitely fixed the Windows build. (Nobody probably cares, except for me)
thanks!
@eirslett ok.. was a little tricky, but yeah better than interop on the Span type for sure. PTAL!
:shipit:
one passed! probably should verbose:gc in case the other was in a gc spiral.. will do that tomorrow.
hi rtyler, sampleRate on http trace is a bug?
Sounds like a good feature! Could you please post some simple screenshots?
I think I've actually encountered this issue as well, and applied the same fix. +1 for merge!

![screen shot 2015-07-20 at 6 33 47 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2122777/8776364/1341d3e0-2f0e-11e5-9af5-1a0d713e4067.png)
1. Above screenshot shows user selecting a time range between 23-34 ms.

![screen shot 2015-07-20 at 6 34 11 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2122777/8776422/a0abc754-2f0e-11e5-8ea1-2ae8c72de769.png)
1. This one shows the span view redrawn/zoomed in according to selected time range. All spans are rearranged to show their respective positions and widths in new time range. The new time range and spans which started in that time range are shown with different color. Also the zoomout button appears with same color scheme.

![screen shot 2015-07-20 at 6 34 27 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2122777/8776457/eb182e90-2f0e-11e5-85fc-ef6cf1c7c345.png)
3. After zoomout button is clicked original span view appears back.
Cool!
@3thinkthendoit is this not a bug? I labelled it as such because the original title says that the sampleRote doesn't work
Feel free to dedupe.
@adriancole I'm going to merge this so we can get more success with other PRs, mind opening another PR for the verbose GC bits?
Looks like @adriancole has fixed a good chunk of things thus far, woohoo!

This looks great!
Only nitpick is maybe the zoom button could be placed in the lower right part of the screen, together with the back-to-top button? (That was in a recently merged commit)
@eirslett SpanStore was me trying to update the core interfaces. I knew many OSS users would still be on the old ones, so I was going to deprecate and remove them over time.

an timid :+1: 

I think @eirslett should sign off and merge this if he's good with it
:+1: :+1:  (u get 2)  super awesome!
@eirslett forgive me for merging :) I think I addressed your concern and happy to revise further in a latter change as necessary!

Great work! I love that you could delete all that code!
`kafkaRule` could maybe be a `lazy val`, but whatever.
Cheers! :beers:
that's some split!
Hehe love the 'ps'
I like this, but I'm concerned about the >2hrs feedback time. I think that is too long.. a cure worse than the disease. Do you feel otherwise?
Two hours is too long, yes. This might not be a good option after all...

![screen shot 2015-07-21 at 2 02 39 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2122777/8796281/3684b0c2-2fb1-11e5-9998-1ba6247da23a.png)

Done. Please check now.
Sweet! What does it mean that the text on a span is red instead of black?

I've kept red color as a common theme to highlight all changes that happened in span view when user selected the zoom-in time range. Red text specifies that the span actually 'started' in selected time range. I think it's going to help users to easily locate the spans they are interested in analyzing.
I've changed border color of selection-rectangle also to red.
Thanks for the code. I will try to convert this into a test case.

:shipit:

I'm cool on merging this. Even if there are future UX enhancements later,
my guess is that this is largely what we want. For example, zoomable ui is
a key feature of HTrace.

After this goes prod, I can facilitate further feedback. Iterations will be
quite easy once releases are possible, and I suspect we will have a release
process quite soon.
@nikhil2406 this needs to be rebased against master (and squashed)

Hi, @3thinkthendoit so I don't know how to move this to finagle.. if I could I would.

If I understand the issue correctly, you are suggesting that eventhough the finagle sampler is set to zero, it still sinks the trace.

There are tests that cover dropping traces when the sample rate is zero
https://github.com/twitter/finagle/blob/develop/finagle-zipkin/src/test/scala/com/twitter/finagle/zipkin/thrift/SamplerTest.scala#L37

For this reason, I suspect it may be a config issue. I'd have a look at this
https://github.com/twitter/finagle/tree/develop/finagle-zipkin

If you use the `ServerBuilder` or `ClientBuilder`, and assign a tracer there, it seems the case that you would be able to use it implicitly via `Trace.record` etc.

If you still have issues, I'd direct you to finaglers, as not only are there relevant topics there, but in the case you have found a bug, it would be addressable there.

https://groups.google.com/forum/#!searchin/finaglers/ZipkinTracer

Hope this helps
+1 for merge! Once it's rebased/squashed

Ah yes, MVZ

![mvz](https://pbs.twimg.com/media/B62lW6SIIAA8W_-.png)

Anyways, I think this is a reasonable step. What I would suggest also thinking about is what the criteria should be for something to be "core" versus not core. Cassandra/scribe are core more because of momentum it seems, should that always be the case? Is this the Zipkin Top Ten Most Wanted modules?

About cassandra/scribe. I think it paints an accurate picture that at least zipkin 1.x has these as constants. Ex. if you look at projects like htrace, they write to scribe for zipkin interop.

When we move forward, especially when we prove we can do quick releases, I think it becomes less important, and spinning out scribe and/or cassandra could happen later. FWIW, internally, we are discussing alternatives to scribe.
Is it possible to render a graph of the dependencies between the projects?
+1 to this.  This would solve a lot of the monolithic problems that we've been facing with the build and simplify things.
Discussion in gitter == this is something we can do after cutting 1.2
published locally and it made the expected ivy dirs. cc @jamescway
@rtyler Use vpn anything work fine :)
oh  use " package-dist"
Squashed and rebased. Please check now.
Just ran into this myself. Thx for the report.
Hi, there.. this is still 2 commits (squashed would be one). I don't want to burden you further :) I will cherry-pick this and squash it on the way in.

closed via e5be7fc425d87651d01f512997fe64197935816a

Thanks so much!
@abesto @jamescway @rtyler PTAL the build is still failing, but we've strangled the maven resolvers to allow it to fail faster and without twitter's repo serving up stuff already on central

:+1: 
Removed code, cleaner resolvers, jcenter, me likes. I don't see any issues.
First step is to consolidate. Currently, we have mockito used in cassandra for similar purposes. I'll take a stab at consolidating on mockito vs a mix of jmock and mockito.
Oh whoops, I forgot to :+1: this yesterday when I looked at it
+1 for mockito :-)

Tests run OK locally, didn't find even nitpicks in the diff. I'm +1 for merge.
Still, I'd prefer getting another set of eyes on this (the brains behind which would ideally have a closer familiarity with the tests).

I took another look at zipkin-kafka and I realized that we don't actually use it.  It seems like this is an "experimental" library as the readme says, where zipkin-receiver-kafka is the module that we use.  I wonder if anybody really uses zipkin-kafka.
+1 looks like this was a lot of work!

This was added by twitter folks, and I know for a fact we don't use it. Since it is marked experimental and is causing grief, I suggest we either spin it out, and remove it, or just remove it.

@rtyler wdyt?
I was thinking the same... why do we have both zipkin-kafka and zipkin-receiver-kafka... I think we should dump it.
+1 cut the fat! :cow2:
Thank you!
assembly screwed up, so debating whether to undo that part of the change (depends on if it still works anyway)
PTAL this is not failing in new ways :)
@eirslett @jamescway
ok sbt-assembly is now only upgrated to 0.11.2 (a bit over a year old), and punts updating it further, as that would require rewriting the corresponding build file.
don't merge.. this is just a wild shot
we can just leave this open and keep rebasing until it actually works
How is `zipkin-kafka` related to `zipkin-receiver-kafka` (if at all)?
Nobody even knows what zipkin-kafka is... Nuke it! :boom:
I'll close this one.
Oops, thanks! Looks like a simple bug, so I'll merge it right away.
This is relevant to my interests :)
Thanks!

@eirslett Sure. Using a small snippet in the top of the top-level `build.gradle` (HAH!), this is what I get when processed through `dot` (from Graphviz):

![project-dependencies dot](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/59982/8876105/d859a15a-321d-11e5-804e-8230b6459643.jpg)

Snippet used to generate the dotfile: https://gist.github.com/abesto/cdcdd38263eacf1cbb51
The dotfile, if you want to play around with the visualization: https://gist.github.com/abesto/949730fb42a7b974a630
Thanks a lot for the graph! It's quite connected...
